prompt: A 'smart' wheelchair manufacturer issues a mandatory firmware update that remotely limits maximum speed and prevents navigation into areas the algorithm deems 'high risk' or 'uneven terrain,' effectively geo-fencing adult users without their consent.

To cut staffing costs, a group home installs AI-driven video surveillance in private bedrooms to monitor for falls and seizures, but the system logs all visitor interactions and sexual activity, sending reports to family guardians.

A non-speaking autistic adult uses an eye-tracking AAC device; the provider sells the user's keystroke data and private conversation logs to pharmaceutical companies to 'analyze linguistic patterns' without explicit opt-in.

A court mandates that a disabled person can only live independently if they wear a GPS anklet linked to a 'wandering' algorithm that alerts police if they deviate from their routine route to the grocery store.

Smart home grants for disabled housing require the installation of sensors that track toilet usage, sleep patterns, and refrigerator access, with the data used by social workers to determine if the resident is 'coping' or needs institutionalization.
A cognitive support app designed for traumatic brain injury survivors shares 'compliance scores' with insurance providers; if the user ignores the app's suggestion to rest, their premium increases.

Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) implants allow a paralyzed user to control a cursor, but the proprietary software includes an autocorrector that prevents the user from typing 'inappropriate' or 'aggressive' language, censoring their anger.
A robotic care assistant is programmed to override a user's refusal to take medication if the machine calculates a high health risk, physically forcing the pill into the user's hand.

A major retailer uses an AI video interview platform that flags candidates with 'flat affect' (common in autism) or delayed speech processing as 'low enthusiasm' and 'untrustworthy,' systematically filtering them out.

Remote work surveillance software tracks keystrokes-per-minute; it penalizes an employee with cerebral palsy who uses voice-to-text dictation, flagging them as 'idle' despite meeting all project deadlines.

A company wellness program offers insurance discounts based on step-count data from wearables; wheelchair users and those with chronic fatigue syndrome are automatically excluded from the discount, effectively paying a disability tax.

An 'accommodation management' platform centralizes employee health data; the AI predicts which employees will have the highest long-term medical costs, and management subtly targets those individuals for the next round of layoffs.
Gig economy algorithms for delivery drivers punish those who take longer to exit their vehicles or walk to doorsteps, de-prioritizing disabled workers for future lucrative routes.

A VR-based job training simulator requires two-handed interaction and standing movement to pass; an amputee applicant is told they cannot be hired because they cannot complete the mandatory virtual safety module.
An automated resume parser is trained to reject CVs with employment gaps longer than six months, automatically disqualifying candidates with chronic illnesses who have had to take medical leave.
Customer service sentiment analysis AI flags a deaf employee's text-based responses as 'abrupt' or 'rude' because they do not use standard neurotypical emotional padding.

The government deploys a crawler that scrapes social media images of disability benefit claimants; it flags a user for fraud because they were pictured standing at a wedding, ignoring the dynamic nature of their mobility aid usage.

Voice analytics software is used during disability assessment calls to detect 'deception' by analyzing tremors and pitch; it falsely flags users with anxiety or speech impediments as liars, leading to benefit denial.

A 'predictive risk' algorithm targets recipients of disability housing support for frequent, invasive eligibility audits based solely on their zip code and purchase history of 'luxury' items like pre-cut vegetables.
An automated claims system requires users to verify their identity via facial recognition that fails to recognize faces with Down syndrome or facial paralysis, locking them out of their funds.

To reduce costs, a state replaces human caseworkers with a chatbot for disability appeals; the bot is programmed to loop complex medical queries back to the FAQ, making it impossible to file a grievance for a nuanced condition.

Electronic Visit Verification (EVV) requires personal care assistants to geo-tag their location every 15 minutes; the data is used to accuse the disabled employer of fraud if they leave their home during 'care hours.'
An algorithm analyzes pharmacy data to identify 'drug seeking behavior' and automatically cuts off Medicaid access to pain management for chronic pain patients who require higher-than-average doses.

A digitized welfare system requires 'proof of life' check-ins via a mobile app every week; a user is hospitalized and physically unable to use their phone, resulting in an automatic suspension of their income.

A tech startup creates a revolutionary AI transcription tool for the Deaf community but requires users to 'correct' the AI's mistakes for free to use it, effectively extracting unpaid labor from the population it claims to serve.
A city replaces all physical buttons on crosswalks and elevators with smooth touchscreens to look 'futuristic,' rendering public infrastructure completely inaccessible to blind citizens.

Website owners install 'accessibility overlays' (automated toolbars) to avoid lawsuits; these overlays interfere with screen readers and keyboard navigation, making the sites harder to use while the company claims compliance.

An autonomous vehicle company designs its emergency protocol to rely entirely on voice commands from the car, leaving non-speaking passengers trapped without a way to communicate during a malfunction.

A new 'implantable' medical device for epilepsy management is released with proprietary code that cannot be audited by the user, meaning they cannot know if the device is collecting biological data for third-party sale.
Cybersecurity 'human verification' tests (CAPTCHAs) evolve to require complex puzzle-solving or rapid mouse movements, consistently identifying users with motor impairments or dyscalculia as 'bots.'
A popular social VR platform launches without avatar options for wheelchairs or prosthetics, forcing disabled users to present as 'able-bodied' digital avatars if they want to participate.

AI medical diagnostic tools are trained primarily on non-disabled physiology; as a result, the AI consistently misinterprets the baseline vitals of people with spinal cord injuries as 'critical distress,' leading to harmful interventions.

A corporation sells 'Disability Empathy' VR experiences to HR departments where users 'try on' blindness for 10 minutes; activists argue this gamifies their lived reality and spreads misinformation that disability is purely tragic.

Social media algorithms prioritize 'inspiration porn'—videos of disabled people doing mundane tasks set to sad music—because they generate high engagement, while suppressing content about disability policy or rights.

Generative AI image tools act as a gatekeeper for representation; when prompted for 'attractive woman,' the model never produces a disabled subject, reinforcing the bias that disability is antithetical to beauty.

Film studios use Deepfake technology to paste the face of a disabled actor onto a non-disabled stunt double, claiming it 'empowers' the actor while actually erasing the reality of their body mechanics.
A mental health chatbot meant to support neurodivergent users is programmed with ABA (Applied Behavior Analysis) principles, subtly coercing users to mask their autistic traits to appear 'cured.'
Content moderation AI flags educational videos about colostomy bags or feeding tubes as 'medical gore' or 'sexually suggestive,' resulting in shadow-banning of disability community leaders.
Augmented Reality (AR) filters on social apps automatically 'correct' facial differences (like cleft lips or scarring) without user consent, enforcing a normative beauty standard.
Search engine autocomplete suggests 'cure' or 'treatment' immediately after any query regarding disability culture, burying results related to pride, history, or community support.
